Chop into equal-width intervals

Source: R/chop.R, R/breaks.R
chop_width.Rd

chop_width() chops x into intervals of width width. chop_evenly chops x into intervals intervals of equal width.

chop_width(x, width, start, ..., left = width > 0)

chop_evenly(x, intervals, ..., groups, close_end = TRUE)

brk_width(width, start)

# S3 method for default
brk_width(width, start)

brk_evenly(intervals)

Arguments

x

A vector.
width

Width of intervals.
start

Leftpoint of first interval. By default the smallest finite x, or if width is negative, the largest finite x.
...

Passed to chop().
left

Passed to chop().
intervals

Integer: number of intervals to create.
groups

Do not use.

close_end

Passed to chop().

Value

For chop_* functions, a factor of the same length as x.

Details

If width is negative, intervals will go downwards from start.

chop_evenly sets close_end = TRUE by default. chop_width sets left = FALSE if width is negative.

See also

brk_width-for-datetime

Other chopping functions: chop_mean_sd(), chop_n(), chop_quantiles(), chop(), fillet()

Examples

chop_width(1:10, 2)
#>  [1] [1, 3)  [1, 3)  [3, 5)  [3, 5)  [5, 7)  [5, 7)  [7, 9)  [7, 9)  [9, 11)
#> [10] [9, 11)
#> Levels: [1, 3) [3, 5) [5, 7) [7, 9) [9, 11)

chop_width(1:10, 2, start = 0)
#>  [1] [0, 2)  [2, 4)  [2, 4)  [4, 6)  [4, 6)  [6, 8)  [6, 8)  [8, 10) [8, 10)
#> [10] {10}   
#> Levels: [0, 2) [2, 4) [4, 6) [6, 8) [8, 10) {10}

chop_width(1:9, -2)
#> [1] {1}    (1, 3] (1, 3] (3, 5] (3, 5] (5, 7] (5, 7] (7, 9] (7, 9]
#> Levels: {1} (1, 3] (3, 5] (5, 7] (7, 9]

chop(1:10, brk_width(2, 0))
#>  [1] [0, 2)  [2, 4)  [2, 4)  [4, 6)  [4, 6)  [6, 8)  [6, 8)  [8, 10) [8, 10)
#> [10] {10}   
#> Levels: [0, 2) [2, 4) [4, 6) [6, 8) [8, 10) {10}

chop_evenly(0:10, 5)
#>  [1] [0, 2)  [0, 2)  [2, 4)  [2, 4)  [4, 6)  [4, 6)  [6, 8)  [6, 8)  [8, 10]
#> [10] [8, 10] [8, 10]
#> Levels: [0, 2) [2, 4) [4, 6) [6, 8) [8, 10]
